Egg Drop Soup with Chicken Broth

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to the comforting world of Egg Drop Soup, a classic dish that embodies warmth and simplicity! Whether you’re looking for a quick weeknight dinner or a soothing remedy for a chilly day, this Egg Drop Soup with Chicken Broth is the perfect solution. With just a handful of ingredients like chicken broth, eggs, and green onions, you can whip up this delightful soup in no time. Not only is it delicious, but it’s also packed with nutrients, making it a great choice for families or anyone seeking a healthy meal option. Join me as we explore the easy steps to create this traditional Chinese dish that’s loved around the globe!

Ingredients

chicken broth

Choose a low-sodium chicken broth for better control over flavor. If you don't have chicken broth, vegetable broth or homemade stock can be good substitutes. For a richer taste, consider adding a splash of soy sauce or a few drops of sesame oil.

eggs

Use the freshest eggs possible for the best flavor and texture. You can substitute with egg whites or silken tofu for a lighter version, but the texture will differ. For added richness, consider using organic or free-range eggs.

cornstarch

Cornstarch is a great thickening agent. If you don't have it, you can substitute with an equal amount of arrowroot powder or potato starch. To avoid lumps, always mix cornstarch with a small amount of cold water before adding it to hot liquids.

water

Using filtered water can improve the overall taste of your soup. You can also use additional chicken broth instead of water to enhance the flavor when making the cornstarch slurry.

green onions

Green onions add a fresh crunch and flavor. If you don’t have them, chives or shallots can be used as substitutes. For a more robust flavor, consider lightly sautéing them before adding to the soup.

salt

Always add salt gradually and taste as you go to avoid over-seasoning. If you're watching your sodium intake, consider using a salt substitute or simply enhance flavor with herbs and spices instead.

white pepper

White pepper has a different flavor profile than black pepper, with a more earthy taste. If unavailable, you can use black pepper, but it may alter the soup’s appearance slightly. For a unique twist, try adding a pinch of ground ginger or cayenne pepper for added warmth.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Chicken Broth

    In a medium saucepan, bring 4 cups of chicken broth to a gentle boil over medium heat. This will be the base for your soup, providing a rich flavor.

  • Step 2: Create the Cornstarch Slurry

    In a small bowl, mix 1 tablespoon of cornstarch with 2 tablespoons of water until smooth. This slurry will help thicken your soup. Make sure to mix it well to avoid lumps.

  • Step 3: Thicken the Broth

    Once the broth is boiling, slowly stir in the cornstarch slurry. Keep stirring until the broth slightly thickens, which should take about 1-2 minutes. This step is crucial for a silky texture.

  • Step 4: Beat the Eggs

    In a separate bowl, beat 2 eggs until they are fully combined. This will help create those beautiful ribbons of egg in the soup.

  • Step 5: Add the Eggs to the Soup

    Slowly drizzle the beaten eggs into the boiling soup while stirring gently. This will create delicate ribbons of egg throughout the soup. Make sure to stir continuously to prevent the eggs from clumping.

  • Step 6: Season the Soup

    Add 2 chopped green onions to the soup for flavor and garnish. Then season with salt and white pepper to taste. Start with a little and adjust according to your preference.

  • Step 7: Serve Hot

    Remove the soup from heat and ladle it into bowls. Serve hot, garnished with extra green onions if desired. Enjoy your homemade Egg Drop Soup!

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I prepare ingredients for Egg Drop Soup?

Start by chopping the green onions and setting them aside. Beat the eggs in a bowl until well mixed. Measure out the chicken broth, cornstarch, and water before you begin cooking to streamline the process.

What should I do if my soup doesn't thicken?

Make sure to mix the cornstarch and water thoroughly to create a smooth slurry before adding it to the boiling broth. Stir continuously as you add it, and allow the broth to boil for a minute or two after adding to achieve a slight thickening.

Can I adjust the seasoning in Egg Drop Soup?

Absolutely! Taste the soup after adding salt and white pepper, and adjust according to your preference. Remember to start with a little, as you can always add more but can't take it out.

Is it safe to add the eggs directly to boiling broth?

To create the signature ribbons of egg in the soup, you should drizzle the beaten eggs slowly while stirring the broth. This gradual incorporation helps to cook the eggs evenly and safely.

What if I don't have white pepper?

You can use black pepper as a substitute. It will slightly change the flavor and appearance, but it will still be delicious!

How can I make sure I don’t overcook the eggs?

When you drizzle the beaten eggs into the boiling broth, do it slowly and stir gently. The eggs will cook quickly, so as soon as you see them forming ribbons, you can remove the soup from heat.

How do I know when the soup is ready to serve?

The soup is ready when it has a slight thickness from the cornstarch and the eggs have formed delicate ribbons. It should be steaming hot and fragrant!

Can I add other ingredients to this soup?

Yes! Feel free to add vegetables like peas or carrots, or proteins like shredded chicken or tofu to enhance the soup. Just make sure to adjust cooking times accordingly.

What type of chicken broth should I use?

You can use homemade or store-bought chicken broth. For a richer flavor, choose a low-sodium option so you can control the saltiness better.

How do I store leftover Egg Drop Soup?

Store any leftover soup in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Reheat gently on the stove, adding a little water if needed to loosen the consistency.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This dish is naturally gluten-free and can easily be made low-carb by omitting the cornstarch if you're looking for a lighter version. For a vegetarian option, substitute the chicken broth with a vegetable broth and ensure the cornstarch is gluten-free. For vegan diets, you can use a silken tofu blend instead of eggs to create a similar texture.

Pairings

For a delightful dining experience, serve the Egg Drop Soup with Chicken Broth alongside crispy spring rolls or dumplings for added texture and flavor. A light soy sauce or ponzu sauce can complement these appetizers beautifully. For beverages, consider pairing with a chilled jasmine tea or a light, dry white wine like Sauvignon Blanc, which will enhance the flavors without overwhelming the palate.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the soup in warm bowls to retain the heat, garnished with additional chopped green onions and a sprinkle of sesame oil for a nutty aroma. You could also offer a drizzle of sriracha or chili oil on the side for those who enjoy a spicy kick. If hosting a larger gathering, consider presenting the soup in a stylish tureen, allowing guests to serve themselves, which adds a communal feel to the meal.

Egg Drop Soup with Chicken Broth

Description

A warm and comforting soup that's quick to make, featuring silky eggs and savory chicken broth.

Ingredients

  • chicken broth: 4 cups
  • eggs: 2
  • cornstarch: 1 tablespoon
  • water: 2 tablespoons
  • green onions: 2, chopped
  • salt: to taste
  • white pepper: to taste
